Hi Joost,

I'm glad you liked the game and thank you very much for your ver=
y
insightful comments! I forwarded them to Daniel as well.

I agree with al=
l your suggestions and observation and we will certainly
address them in th=
e second version of the game.
Also, thanks to all who played the game and g=
enerated data for Daniel's
master thesis :) I'm looking forward to sharing =
these results with you.

Cheers,
Sebastian


On Mon, Aug 11, 2014 at 6:55 A=
M, Joost Huizinga joost.hui@... [neat] <
neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:=


>
>
> Hello Sebastian and Julian,
>
> First of all, I think this game is =
a great idea and an impressive result!
> It is one of those ideas that I al=
ways wanted to try, to test wether it is
> fun to play and to see what kind=
 of innovations might be produced in the
> hands of a large player base, bu=
t I never felt I had enough time,
> experience or motivation to start devel=
opment.
>
> As for my experience playing the game, I think the tutorial mes=
sages were
> very good, but I couldn't shake the feeling of being a bit los=
t on the
> brain training screen. I mean, the game told me that I should ev=
olve a
> brain to follow and a brain to flee, but during training I got lit=
tle
> feedback on if I was doing things right or not. Maybe it would help i=
f you
> could select a target behavior during training such that the game c=
ould
> give you better feedback on your progress.
>
> Also, despite the too=
ltips, some of the objectives weren't very clear to
> me. For example, I am=
 not sure what the exact difference is between keeping
> a certain distance=
 and reaching a certain distance, nor how exactly this
> interacts with the=
 '- Distance' slider. For example, I assumed that keeping
> a distance of 1=
 meter would cause the robots to drive towards the target
> and stop at 1 m=
eter distance, but looking at the results and numbers during
> evolution I =
am really not sure if that is true. Another example is the
> 'move around' =
objective. When I tried to evolve a brain that would stand
> still and do n=
othing I set the 'move around' slider to -100. When I ran
> evolution, rath=
er than standing still the robots would instead start to
> move towards the=
 center of the arena. That said, the weapon based
> objectives were clear t=
o me, and seemed to work as expected.
>
> Lastly, I think that the numbers =
shown during evolution are a bit
> confusing. For example, at some point I =
had something like a 'Best Fitness'
> of 1049, an 'Evolution' of +623 and a=
 'Keep distance' of 5115, and I had no
> clue how those numbers were suppos=
ed to relate to each other. I mean, my
> fitness wasn't improving by +623 b=
ecause my previous fitness was also
> around 1000, and I didn't know how a =
'Keep distance' of 5115 would
> translate to a fitness of 1049. I wonder if=
 there are ways to make these
> numbers more intuitive.
>
> That said, I di=
d have some fun with game (I managed to beat the final
> boss), and I am lo=
oking forward to any updates and expansions, if they are
> planned. Making =
a compelling game based on evolutionary algorithms is a
> difficult but int=
eresting challenge, and this game provides a great start.
>
> Best regards,=

> Joost Huizinga
>
>
> On Sun, Aug 10, 2014 at 6:03 PM, Sebastian Risi seb=
astian.risi@...
> [neat] <neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>>
>>
>> Hi =
all,
>>
>> I'm happy to announce our new game Evolve, made by Daniel Jallov=
, a
>> master student at ITU supervised by myself and Julian Togelius.
>>
>=
> The game consists of two major parts: an evolution part where neural
>> n=
etworks are evolved using NEAT, and a battle part where players use the
>> =
evolved networks to control their robots. The goal of the project is to
>> =
investigate whether giving the player indirect control over the robot (by
>=
> switching brains in battle) is an engaging game mechanic and whether it
>=
> makes sense to put the AI in the hands of the player.
>>
>> Check it out =
here: http://jallov.com/thesis/
>>
>> Looking forward to your comments!
>>
=
>> Cheers,
>> Sebastian
>>
>> From the webpage:
>>
>> "Evolve is a game abo=
ut becoming the greatest robot trainer of all time.
>> Your mission is to t=
each a simple robot how to fight and ultimately take it
>> to the Champion=
=E2=80=99s arena to battle against other trainers. To reach this
>> goal, y=
ou must teach your robot how to move and how to fight, and you must
>> have=
 the tactical nouse to tell your robot what to do in the heat of
>> battle.=
 Your robot will gradually become more advanced as you progress
>> through =
the missions, and when the missions are completed you will be ready
>> to b=
attle online against other players."
>>
>>
>> --
>> Dr. Sebastian Risi
>> A=
ssistant Professor
>> IT University of Copenhagen, Room 5D08
>> Rued Langga=
ards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen, Denmark
>> email: sebastian.risi@..., we=
b: www.sebastianrisi.com
>> mobile: +45-50250355, office: +45-7218-5127
>>
=
>>
>  
>

Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

<div dir=3D"ltr">Hi Joost,<div><br></div><div>I'm glad you liked the ga=
me and thank you very much for your very insightful comments! I forwarded t=
hem to Daniel as well.</div><div><br></div><div>I agree with all your sugge=
stions and observation and we will certainly address them in the second ver=
sion of the game.=C2=A0</div>
<div>Also, thanks to all who played the game =
and generated data for Daniel's master thesis :) I'm looking forwar=
d to sharing these results with you.</div><div><br></div><div>Cheers,</div>=
<div>Sebastian</div></div>
<div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><br><div class=3D=
"gmail_quote">On Mon, Aug 11, 2014 at 6:55 AM, Joost Huizinga <a href=3D"ma=
ilto:joost.hui@...">joost.hui@...</a> [neat] <span dir=3D"ltr">=
<<a href=3D"mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogro=
ups.com</a>></span> wrote:<br>
<blockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=
=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;padding-left:1ex">


<u></=
u>









 
<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<span>=C2=A0</span>


<=
div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hello =
Sebastian and Julian,<div><br></div><div>First of all, I think this game is=
 a great idea and an impressive result! It is one of those ideas that I alw=
ays wanted to try, to test wether it is fun to play and to see what kind of=
 innovations might be produced in the hands of a large player base, but I n=
ever felt I had enough time, experience or motivation to start development.=
</div>

<div><br></div><div>As for my experience playing the game, I think =
the tutorial messages were very good, but I couldn't shake the feeling =
of being a bit lost on the brain training screen. I mean, the game told me =
that I should evolve a brain to follow and a brain to flee, but during trai=
ning I got little feedback on if I was doing things right or not. Maybe it =
would help if you could select a target behavior during training such that =
the game could give you better feedback on your progress.</div>

<div><br><=
/div><div>Also, despite the tooltips, some of the objectives weren't ve=
ry clear to me. For example, I am not sure what the exact difference is bet=
ween keeping a certain distance and reaching a certain distance, nor how ex=
actly this interacts with the '- Distance' slider. For example, I a=
ssumed that keeping a distance of 1 meter would cause the robots to drive t=
owards the target and stop at 1 meter distance, but looking at the results =
and numbers during evolution I am really not sure if that is true. Another =
example is the 'move around' objective. When I tried to evolve a br=
ain that would stand still and do nothing I set the 'move around' s=
lider to -100. When I ran evolution, rather than standing still the robots =
would instead start to move towards the center of the arena. That said, the=
 weapon based objectives were clear to me, and seemed to work as expected.<=
/div>

<div><br></div><div>Lastly, I think that the numbers shown during ev=
olution are a bit confusing. For example, at some point I had something lik=
e a 'Best Fitness' of 1049, an 'Evolution' of +623 and a &#=
39;Keep distance' of 5115, and I had no clue how those numbers were sup=
posed to relate to each other. I mean, my fitness wasn't improving by +=
623 because my previous fitness was also around 1000, and I didn't know=
 how a 'Keep distance' of 5115 would translate to a fitness of 1049=
. I wonder if there are ways to make these numbers more intuitive.</div>

<=
div><br></div><div>That said, I did have some fun with game (I managed to b=
eat the final boss), and I am looking forward to any updates and expansions=
, if they are planned. Making a compelling game based on evolutionary algor=
ithms is a difficult but interesting challenge, and this game provides a gr=
eat start.</div>

<div><br></div><div>Best regards,</div><div>Joost Huizing=
a</div></div><div><div class=3D"h5"><div class=3D"gmail_extra"><br><br><div=
 class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sun, Aug 10, 2014 at 6:03 PM, Sebastian Risi <a h=
ref=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." target=3D"_blank">sebastian.risi@gm=
ail.com</a> [neat] <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:neat@yahoogroups=
.com" target=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>></span> wrote:<br>

<bl=
ockquote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"border-left:1px #ccc solid">


<u><=
/u>









 
<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">
<span>=C2=A0</span>


=
<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p></p><div dir=3D"ltr">Hi al=
l,<br><br>I'm happy to announce our new game Evolve, made by Daniel Jal=
lov, a master student at ITU supervised by myself and Julian Togelius.<br><=
br>The game consists of two major parts: an evolution part where neural net=
works are evolved using NEAT, and a battle part where players use the evolv=
ed networks to control their robots. The goal of the project is to investig=
ate whether giving the player indirect control over the robot (by switching=
 brains in battle) is an engaging game mechanic and whether it makes sense =
to put the AI in the hands of the player.<br>


<br>Check it out here: <a h=
ref=3D"http://jallov.com/thesis/" target=3D"_blank">http://jallov.com/thesi=
s/</a><br><br>Looking forward to your comments!<br><br>Cheers,<br>Sebastian=
<br><br>From the webpage:<br><br>"Evolve is a game about becoming the =
greatest robot trainer of all time. Your mission is to teach a simple robot=
 how to fight and ultimately take it to the Champion=E2=80=99s arena to bat=
tle against other trainers. To reach this goal, you must teach your robot h=
ow to move and how to fight, and you must have the tactical nouse to tell y=
our robot what to do in the heat of battle. Your robot will gradually becom=
e more advanced as you progress through the missions, and when the missions=
 are completed you will be ready to battle online against other players.&qu=
ot;<br>


<br><br>--<br>Dr. Sebastian Risi<br>Assistant Professor<br>IT Uni=
versity of Copenhagen, Room 5D08<br>Rued Langgaards Vej 7, 2300 Copenhagen,=
 Denmark<br>email: <a href=3D"mailto:sebastian.risi@..." target=3D"_b=
lank">sebastian.risi@...</a>, web: <a href=3D"http://www.sebastianris=
i.com" target=3D"_blank">www.sebastianrisi.com</a><br>


mobile: <a href=3D=
"tel:%2B45-50250355" value=3D"+4550250355" target=3D"_blank">+45-50250355</=
a>, office: <a href=3D"tel:%2B45-7218-5127" value=3D"+4572185127" target=3D=
"_blank">+45-7218-5127</a><br></div>
<p></p>

    </div>
